title: Corners in Quasirandom Groups via Sparse Mixing

sections.corners in quasirandom groups:
The notion of quasirandom groups was introduced by Gowers  in studying product-free sets. Quasirandom groups enjoy the property that for any two large sets A,BâŠ‚Gğ´ğµğºA,B\subset G, the distribution obtained by taking uniform random samples aâˆˆAğ‘ğ´a\in A, bâˆˆBğ‘ğµb\in B and outputting aâ€‹bğ‘ğ‘ab is close to uniform in an L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-sense. Of course, abelian groups fail to satisfy the mixing property mentioned above. In ğ”½2nsuperscriptsubscriptğ”½2ğ‘›\mathbb{F}_{2}^{n} for instance, a subspace Vğ‘‰V of codimension 1 is very dense, but V+V=Vğ‘‰ğ‘‰ğ‘‰V+V=V is far from being uniform. We now present the formal definition. A finite group GğºG is Dğ·D-quasirandom if every nontrivial irreducible representation over â„‚â„‚\mathbb{C} has dimension at least Dğ·D. One can show that every irreducible representation of a finite group GğºG must have dimension at most |G|ğº\sqrt{|G|}. We record this fact for later use, which can be found in most introductory texts on representation theory of finite groups. For example, this follows from Proposition 5 in [48, Chapter 2.4]. Every complex irreducible representation of a finite group GğºG has dimension at most |G|ğº\sqrt{|G|}. There are choices of groups GğºG which are Dğ·D-quasirandom for D=|G|Î©â€‹(1)ğ·superscriptğºÎ©1D=|G|^{\Omega(1)}. Contrast this with abelian groups, where every irreducible representation has dimension 1. A common example of a quasirandom group is the set of 2Ã—2222\times 2 matrices over the finite field ğ”½psubscriptğ”½ğ‘\mathbb{F}_{p} for pğ‘p prime with determinant 1.
A classical result of Frobenius  shows that every nontrivial irreducible representation of SL2â€‹(ğ”½p)subscriptSL2subscriptğ”½ğ‘\mathrm{SL}_{2}(\mathbb{F}_{p}) has dimension at least pâˆ’12âˆ¼|G|1/3similar-toğ‘12superscriptğº13\frac{p-1}{2}\sim|G|^{1/3}. (For exposition of these facts and additional background on quasirandom groups, see e.g.Â .) Quasirandom groups have seen various application in constructing pseudorandom objects. The Ramanujan graphs of Lubotzky, Phillips, and Sarnak [ref]36 are built from Cayley graphs of PSL2â€‹(ğ”½p)subscriptPSL2subscriptğ”½ğ‘\mathrm{PSL}_{2}(\mathbb{F}_{p}) for specific choices of pğ‘p. (The group PSL2â€‹(ğ”½p)subscriptPSL2subscriptğ”½ğ‘\mathrm{PSL}_{2}(\mathbb{F}_{p}) is obtained by quotienting SL2â€‹(ğ”½p)subscriptSL2subscriptğ”½ğ‘\mathrm{SL}_{2}(\mathbb{F}_{p}) by its center.) Bourgain and Gamburd  showed that random Cayley graphs on SL2â€‹(ğ”½p)subscriptSL2subscriptğ”½ğ‘\mathrm{SL}_{2}(\mathbb{F}_{p}) are expanders. The quasirandomness property was useful for arguing about the multiplicity of eigenvalues of the Cayley graph. Outside of graph theory, ideas from the study of quasirandom groups led to an optimal inapproximability result for kğ‘˜k-LIN over non-abelian groups . A recent work of Derksen, Lee, and Viola  building on  proved kğ‘˜k-NOF lower bounds for computing an â€œinterleaved productâ€ of elements coming from a quasirandom group. In particular, their bounds are best understood in the regime where kğ‘˜k is growing, and they match that of . The most useful property of quasirandom groups is that convolutions of large sets mix. More formally, we have the following: Let GğºG be a Dğ·D-quasirandom group and f,g:Gâ†’â„:ğ‘“ğ‘”â†’ğºâ„f,g:G\to\mathbb{R}, and assume at least one has mean zero. Then There are various proofs of this fact    which use representation theory. Over abelian groups, convolutions and L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}-norms have pleasant interpretations when working in the Fourier basis. Many of these statements have clean analogs over non-abelian groups which can be formulated using representation theory. TheoremÂ 4.6 can be used to count solutions to equations in quasirandom groups.  did exactly this to argue about the size of product-free sets in quasirandom groups.
